description:
Apiotrichum porosum is a species of fungus that belongs to the Basidiomycota phylum. It is a wood-rotting fungus that is commonly found growing on the decaying wood of various tree species.

The fungus produces small, poroid (pore-bearing) fruiting bodies that are typically white to greyish-white in color. The pores on the underside of the fruiting body are small and densely packed. The fungus is known to cause a type of wood decay called white rot, which involves the degradation of both the cellulose and lignin components of the wood.

Apiotrichum porosum is considered an important decomposer in forest ecosystems, playing a role in the recycling of nutrients by breaking down dead and decaying wood. It is also of interest to researchers due to its potential applications in bioremediation and the production of valuable enzymes for industrial processes.
